abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews Bedell Cellars' 1996 chardonnay and Schneider Vineyards' 1998 chardonnay; photo (Long Island Vines column) (M)

block.p: The silver foil covering the cork on Kip Bedell's 1996 chardonnay suggests its quicksilver use at the table.
Simple in character, and in price ($10), this chardonnay is made to order for simple fish and chicken dishes, for pork and for veal.
The silver foil covering the cork on Kip Bedell's 1996 chardonnay suggests its quicksilver use at the table.
Simple in character, and in price ($10), this chardonnay is made to order for simple fish and chicken dishes, for pork and for veal.

But not for an aperitif. The 1996 growing season was cool and damp, ripening was difficult, and acids were high. Even though Mr. Bedell put this white through a secondary fermentation to reduce the acidity, it is so brisk it needs food as a complement.
Likewise, another, younger North Fork chardonnay, the Schneider Vineyards '98, is also a useful dinner companion.
Both wines are light-bodied, lean and refreshing, with not a smidgen of California plumpness; both pique the appetite in a tart Granny Smith way.
Unless I misperceive their structures, both are a year away from their fullest development, although the Bedell, particularly in its brushed-gold color, has begun to display the patina of age.
If you serve the wines cold, they may come across as harsh and near-tasteless, but if they are mildly cool, even verging on tepid, the flavors come alive.
As the delicately oaky Bedell chardonnay warms up, tones of honey become honey-butterscotch and carry over into a longish finish.

The pale-colored Schneider chardonnay ($19), also with honey in its aroma (and apple blossoms, too), offers a spiciness and smokiness as it warms up. Right now, the extended finish is tasty. But overall, the wine is so closed or inward -- tight, in wine jargon -- that it counsels consumer patience.
Schneider, currently developing an estate in Riverhead, contracted with Palmer, in Aquebogue, to make this chardonnay from purchased grapes.
